title: US Fed to resume buying assets early next year to temper financing challenges and unease
body: The Federal Reserve plans to resume asset purchases early next year to help temper investor unease about the U.S. government’s financing challenges. This comes after the Federal Reserve concluded its three-year run of quantitative tightening and signaled that the central bank will resume being a major buyer of U.S. Treasuries. Chair Jerome Powell commented, “At a certain point, you’ll want . . . reserves to start gradually growing to keep up with the size of the banking system and the size of the economy.” Marco Casiraghi of Evercore ISI also noted that the Fed would begin buying Treasuries again in the first quarter of next year, aiming to expand its balance sheet by March at the latest. The Federal Reserve’s quantitative tightening program, which began in 2022, aimed to reduce the central bank’s holdings of Treasury and mortgage-backed securities accumulated during pandemic-era quantitative easing. QT has been steadily reducing Fed holdings since that peak. Nearly all of the QT that has transpired this far has taken the form of eliminating the excess of cash that the firms eligible to do business with the Fed had deposited in the reverse repo facility, which peaked at $2.6 trillion at the end of 2022, and is now experiencing a nearly complete lack of activity. From now on, the Fed will move forward with a balance sheet that’s considerably more significant than the $4.2 trillion level seen at the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic. U.S. markets have eased their anxiety about the country’s supply pressures Casiraghi projected that the Fed would purchase around $35 billion worth of Treasuries per month, translating into a $20 billion monthly expansion of its $6.6 trillion balance sheet. He also noted the Fed will drop some of its mortgage-backed assets. The Fed’s actions are intended to restore confidence among investors uneasy about the government’s debt sustainability. So far, markets have calmed somewhat, with traders expecting the Fed to end its quantitative tightening. Fund managers were also optimistic that the U.S. deficit, currently at 6% of GDP, may shrink. Mark Cabana, head of U.S. rates strategy at Bank of America, even noted that markets seem far less anxious about supply pressures than before. He remarked, “Concerns about the deficit worsening have been cooled due to strong tariff revenues, and the expectation that the Fed will soon start buying [government debt].” The 10-year U.S. Treasury yield, a bellwether for global borrowing, has already dropped from 4.8% in January to under 4.1%, thanks to a sustained rally since the summer, primarily driven by expectations that the Fed will soon lower rates. Casiraghi asserts that the Fed does not intend to extend QT at the moment The yield spread between U.S. 10-year Treasuries and interest swaps of the same maturity has narrowed sharply since April’s peak, dropping to roughly 0.16 percentage points. Typically, bond yields and swap rates remain closely aligned, as they both reflect expectations for future interest rates. But in the U.S. and U.K., yields have outpaced swaps this year as investors demanded extra yield to take on growing government debt. Yields on 30-year U.S. bonds are now just one percentage point higher than on 2-year notes, down from over 1.3 in September. Meanwhile, the gap between 10-year U.K. government bond yields and swap rates has narrowed to roughly 0.25 percentage points from almost 0.4 percentage points in April. The Fed’s decision to call off its quantitative tightening path came along when signs appeared that the central bank’s attempt to lift liquidity was destabilizing short-term funding markets The purchases indicate that banks have more than sufficient reserves. To put this into perspective, in the past, quantitative easing engaged trillions of dollars in debt buys during downturns. Casiraghi even explained that quantitative easing is designed to boost liquidity aggressively during times of crisis. In contrast, the Fed’s goal now is simply to ensure the system has enough reserves to implement policy effectively. title: Binance Unveils CC Perpetual Futures: A Game-Changer for Crypto Traders?
body: BitcoinWorld Binance Unveils CC Perpetual Futures: A Game-Changer for Crypto Traders? The world of cryptocurrency trading is constantly evolving, with new opportunities emerging for savvy investors. Binance, a leading global exchange, has just made an exciting announcement that’s set to capture the attention of many: the listing of CC perpetual futures on its pre-market. This move could significantly impact how traders engage with specific digital assets, offering both exciting prospects and new challenges. What Exactly Are CC Perpetual Futures, Anyway? Before diving into the implications, it is crucial to understand what CC perpetual futures entail. In essence, a perpetual futures contract is a type of derivatives product that allows traders to speculate on the future price of an asset without an expiry date. Unlike traditional futures, which have a set settlement date, perpetual futures can be held indefinitely, mimicking spot market prices through a funding rate mechanism. No Expiry Date: Traders do not need to worry about rolling over contracts. Leverage: These contracts typically allow for significant leverage, amplifying both potential gains and losses. Price Tracking: They aim to track the underlying asset’s spot price closely, making them a popular tool for hedging and speculation. The ‘CC’ in CC perpetual futures refers to a specific underlying asset or index, which Binance is now making available for trading in a novel way. Why Is Binance’s Move on CC Perpetual Futures a Game-Changer? Binance’s decision to list CC perpetual futures on its pre-market is a significant development for several reasons. Pre-market listings often allow early price discovery and provide an initial liquidity pool before the official trading launch. This can give early participants a unique advantage, allowing them to gauge market sentiment and position themselves accordingly. Moreover, introducing new perpetual futures contracts on a major exchange like Binance typically leads to: Increased Liquidity: Attracting more traders and capital to the specific asset. Enhanced Trading Strategies: Providing new tools for arbitrage, hedging, and directional speculation. Market Visibility: Raising the profile of the underlying asset within the broader crypto ecosystem. This listing broadens the scope for advanced trading strategies, making the crypto derivatives market even more dynamic and accessible to a global audience. Navigating the Risks of Trading CC Perpetual Futures While the opportunities presented by CC perpetual futures are compelling, it is equally important to acknowledge the inherent risks. Derivatives trading, especially with leverage, carries a high degree of risk. The volatility of cryptocurrency markets means that prices can fluctuate wildly, leading to rapid liquidation of positions if not managed carefully. Consider these points before engaging: High Leverage: Small price movements can result in substantial losses, potentially exceeding initial capital. Market Volatility: Sudden price swings can trigger stop-loss orders or lead to unexpected liquidations. Funding Rates: These rates can sometimes be significant, impacting profitability, especially for long-term positions. Therefore, a disciplined approach to risk management, including setting appropriate stop-loss levels and only trading with capital you can afford to lose, is absolutely essential. How to Access CC Perpetual Futures on Binance’s Pre-Market For traders eager to participate, accessing CC perpetual futures on Binance’s pre-market requires understanding the platform’s specific procedures. Typically, pre-market trading involves a different set of rules compared to standard spot or futures trading. Users might need to allocate specific funds or meet certain eligibility criteria to participate. Here are some actionable insights for getting started: Check Binance’s Official Announcement: Always refer to the official Binance announcement for precise details on eligibility, trading pairs, and timelines. Understand Pre-Market Mechanics: Familiarize yourself with how pre-market orders are matched and settled. Start Small: Especially if new to derivatives or pre-market trading, begin with smaller positions to gain experience. Implement Risk Management: Use stop-loss orders and position sizing techniques to protect your capital. Binance often provides comprehensive guides for new listings, which can be invaluable resources for navigating these new opportunities responsibly. The introduction of CC perpetual futures on Binance’s pre-market marks another exciting chapter in the evolving cryptocurrency landscape. It opens new avenues for sophisticated traders to engage with digital assets, offering the potential for significant gains through leveraged positions and strategic market timing. However, with great opportunity comes great responsibility. Traders must approach these new instruments with a clear understanding of both their mechanics and the associated risks. By staying informed, practicing diligent risk management, and utilizing Binance’s resources, you can confidently explore the potential that these new offerings bring to your trading portfolio. Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) What is a perpetual futures contract? A perpetual futures contract is a derivative product that allows traders to speculate on the price of an asset without an expiry date, unlike traditional futures. It aims to track the underlying asset’s spot price through a funding rate mechanism. What does ‘pre-market’ listing mean for CC perpetual futures? A pre-market listing allows traders to place orders for a new asset before its official launch on the main exchange. This often facilitates early price discovery and liquidity formation, giving participants a chance to trade before wider market access. What are the main benefits of trading CC perpetual futures? The primary benefits include the ability to use leverage to amplify potential returns, the flexibility of not having an expiry date, and the opportunity to engage in advanced trading strategies like hedging or arbitrage on a specific asset. What are the major risks associated with CC perpetual futures trading? Major risks include high leverage leading to amplified losses, significant market volatility that can cause rapid liquidations, and the impact of funding rates on long-term positions. It is crucial to manage these risks carefully. How can I prepare to trade CC perpetual futures on Binance? To prepare, review Binance’s official announcements for listing details, understand pre-market trading rules, and ensure you have a robust risk management strategy in place, including setting stop-loss orders and managing position sizes. If you found this article insightful, consider sharing it with your network! Spreading awareness about new trading opportunities and the importance of responsible trading helps foster a more informed crypto community. Your shares on social media can help others navigate the exciting world of digital assets.
